title: MPD Influx Response
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are drilling with MPD at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD. Current MW is {{currentSection.mudWeight.current}} ppg with {{scenario.currentSBP}} psi SBP applied. Delta flow monitoring detects a {{scenario.deltaFlow}} gpm increase in returns. What is the correct MPD response sequence?
correctSequence: 1. Stop drilling and pick up off bottom
2. Increase SBP using MPD choke to compensate for influx
3. Monitor pit volume and flow rate
4. If influx controlled with SBP < limit, circulate out micro-influx
5. If SBP approaching limit or influx continues, convert to conventional shut-in

answerOptions.A: Immediately shut in using conventional BOP procedure
answerOptions.B: Increase SBP to control influx, monitor, circulate out if contained
answerOptions.C: Continue drilling and monitor - MPD will handle it automatically
answerOptions.D: Reduce pump rate to decrease ECD and observe

feedback.correct: Correct. MPD's advantage is the ability to dynamically increase surface back pressure to control small influxes without shutting in. Monitor SBP limit ({{wellProfile.mpdData.surfaceBackPressure.max}} psi max) and pit volumes. If the influx continues growing or SBP approaches limits, convert to conventional shut-in.
feedback.A_feedback: Premature. MPD can handle small influxes by increasing SBP. Only convert to conventional shut-in if the influx exceeds MPD capability.
feedback.C_feedback: Incorrect and dangerous. MPD requires active intervention - you must increase SBP to control the influx.
feedback.D_feedback: This would reduce BHP further and worsen the influx. Never reduce BHP when taking an influx.

contextualTip: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, the tight mud weight window means conventional shut-in risks fracturing the formation. MPD's dynamic control allows influx management with less formation stress.
advancedNote: The decision point is when SBP approaches {{wellProfile.mpdData.surfaceBackPressure.max}} psi or pit gain exceeds 10-15 bbls. At that point, the influx has exceeded MPD capability and conventional well control is required.
